courseTitle: Step 2 - Inquiry Based STEM Lesson Design
courseDescription: This course continues the exploration of inquiry-based lesson design in STEM education. In this course, students build upon and practice lesson design skills developed in Step 1 while also becoming familiar with exemplary mathematics or science curricula at the middle school level. With the guidance of the master teacher, students engage in one observation and prepare and teach three inquiry-based lessons in a middle school classroom. Students incorporate and demonstrate their content knowledge in developing the inquiry-based lessons. At the end of Step 2, students are generally ready to make a decision about whether they want to pursue a pathway to teacher licensure through the MonarchTeach program.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with exemplary mathematics or science curricula
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Content knowledge application in lesson development

courseTitle: Foundations of STEM Teaching: An Inquiry-Based Approach
courseDescription: In this introductory STEM teacher preparation course, students delve into the 5-E Model of inquiry-based lesson design within real classroom settings. Guided by mentors and experienced master teachers, students actively engage in authentic hands-on experiences in elementary and middle school classes. Throughout the course, they develop essential skills in effective lesson design, questioning strategies, and the integration of educational technologies. Students are also introduced to mathematics or science curricula, with a focus on developing pre- and post-assessment instruments, analyzing student work, and honing classroom management skills.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing inquiry-based lessons using the 5-E Model
Integration of educational technologies into lesson plans
Development and implementation of mathematics or science curricula
Creation of pre- and post-assessment instruments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Mentorship and collaboration with master teachers and peers
Analyzing and providing feedback on student work
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing student work to improve instruction
Creating and analyzing pre- and post-assessment instruments to measure student learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Designing and implementing effective lesson plans
Collaborating with mentors and master teachers

courseDescription: An overview of the resources and systems of technology.  Emphasis is on impacts that technology has on individuals and their careers.  Activities explore the evolution of technology, its major systems and their impact on individuals and their careers.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of technology resources and systems
Understanding the impact of technology on careers

courseTitle: Knowing and Learning in STEM Education
courseDescription: This course is designed to expand the students' understanding of current theories of learning and conceptual development in STEM. Students will investigate theories of knowing and learning in STEM and implications for teaching secondary mathematics and science. Students will examine their own assumptions about learning as well as critically examine the needs of a diverse student population in the classroom.  Students are expected to independently register for and take the Praxis I examination while enrolled in this course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of STEM theories and conceptual development
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Critical examination of diverse student needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical examination of own learning assumptions
Implications understanding for teaching secondary mathematics and science
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adapting teaching strategies for diverse student needs

courseDescription: This course provides students with an overview of principles for teaching middle and secondary school mathematics or science through an exploration of the role of content, pedagogy, curriculum and technology as they promote learning and impact equity. Students are introduced to ways in which curriculum and technology are used in the classroom to build interrelationships among teachers and students. Frameworks for teaching students of diverse backgrounds equitably are emphasized in the course. A field component that consists of observations and teaching in the high school classroom is included.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adapting STEM curriculum for diverse classroom settings
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Building interrelationships among teachers and students
Communicating complex concepts in an accessible manner
Teaching students of diverse backgrounds equitably
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Navigating challenges in teaching middle and secondary school mathematics or science
Evaluating and adapting curriculum to promote learning and ensure equity
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing observations and teaching in the high school classroom

courseDescription: A study of materials used by industry to produce products.  Emphasis is on the study of ceramics, plastics, composites, and biotechnological materials.  Students learn materials identification, use and processing.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use and processing of biotechnological materials

courseDescription: A study of the production processes used with metallic and forest product materials.  Industrial resources, their location, extraction, and processing into standard stocks are also covered.  Students learn properties, uses and processing of metal and wood materials.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of production processes for metallic and forest product materials
Knowledge of industrial resources extraction and processing
Comprehension of properties, uses, and processing of metal and wood materials
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and analysis of suitable industrial resources
Applying suitable processing methods for different materials
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of resources extraction and processing

courseDescription: A study of direct and alternating current and its use in contemporary technology. Activities include experiments and projects to supplement the theory of electricity.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of direct and alternating current
Application of current in contemporary technology
Project execution related to electricity theory
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Solving problems related to direct and alternating current

courseDescription: Students will develop an understanding of systems control technology for application to energy and power, manufacturing, processing and transportation systems. Emphasis will be placed on research and development, creativity and experimentation, and trouble shooting in designing control systems.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of technology to energy/power systems
Application of technology to manufacturing systems
Application of technology to processing systems
Application of technology to transportation systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in research and development processes

courseDescription: A guided review of communication technology and information sources to help students discern between reliable and unreliable sources and techniques.  Students develop skills in computer applications, information retrieval, filtering and analyzing data, and formatting and presenting information.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Discerning between reliable and unreliable sources

courseDescription: A study of production processes used in manufacturing and construction systems.  Students will research and design manufactured products for mass production and constructed products for building.  The social, cultural, environmental and economic impacts of manufacturing and constructed products on society are discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Assessing the impact of manufactured and constructed products on various societal factors
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining and discussing complex manufacturing and construction concepts
Negotiating and collaborating on design ideas
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying potential economic, environmental, and social impacts of products

courseDescription: A study of the production processes used in manufacturing systems.  Emphasis is placed upon planning, organizing and principles of manufacturing.  Students research and design enterprise systems for mass production.  Emphasis is on manufacturing design requirements and the social, cultural, and economic impacts of manufactured products on society and the environment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing enterprise systems for mass production
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and considering social, cultural, and economic impacts of manufacturing
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating the environmental impact of manufacturing

courseDescription: A course for technology education majors that studies technological systems related to medical and food processing technologies. Students learn the basis of these technologies and complete activities that integrate the content with processes and products found in our technological world.
Technical and Digital Skills: Integration of technological content with processes and products
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication of technological processes and products
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem-solving in the context of medical and food processing technologies

courseDescription: The study of communication design principles and techniques for technology education.  Emphasis is placed on the skills and equipment used in design, production, and distribution of communications.  Print and electronic media are explored through technical illustration, video, audio, and other specialty processes of communications.
Technical and Digital Skills: Proficiency in using equipment for design, production, and distribution
Knowledge of print and electronic media
Mastery of other specialty processes of communications
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Skill in presenting complex technical concepts
Ability to communicate through various media formats
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis and interpretation of communication design principles
Critical evaluation of print and electronic media
Problem solving in communication design and production
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in design and production teams
Organizing and distributing various forms of media

courseDescription: A study of the development and impact of communication technology.  Emphasis is placed on the integration of technical skills to produce information-based products such as print and telecommunications media.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of communication technology
Problem-solving in print and telecommunications media production

courseDescription: Study of the development of energy, power, and transportation systems and the movement of energy, power, people, and cargo.  Areas of concern include vehicle systems design and support systems.

This course introduces safety programs used in the workplace and to increase the safety environment at work. The course covers four key topics: preliminary hazard analysis, failure modes and effects analysis, and OSHA hazard analysis and safety review requirements, which leads to an OSHA 10 Certificate.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementing failure modes and effects analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing safety failures and their effects

courseDescription: Available for pass/fail grading only.  Student participation for credit based on the academic relevance of the work experience, criteria, and evaluative procedures as formally determined by the department and the Cooperative Education program prior to the semester in which the work experience is to take place.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with department and program heads
Negotiating academic relevance of work experience
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Evaluating work experience for academic relevance
Determining relevant criteria for work experience
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in negotiating academic relevance of work experience

courseDescription: A multidisciplinary course designed  to provide insight into the fundamental, historical, and contemporary nature of technology as an area of human knowledge.  Attention is given to the positive and negative aspects of technology and how they affect society.  (This is a writing intensive course.)
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of contemporary and historical technological trends
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing positive and negative aspects of technology

courseTitle: Project Based Instruction in STEM Education
courseDescription: Through a dynamic process of investigation and collaboration, students aim to master techniques for project-based investigations in STEM classrooms, and teach project-based lessons in the secondary classroom. Students work in teams to formulate questions, make predictions, design investigations, collect and analyze data, make products and share ideas. The use of assessments to improve student learning is emphasized in the course. This course includes a field component that consists of two observation days and three teaching days in a secondary classroom.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching project-based lessons in a secondary classroom
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Assessment utilization for student learning improvement

courseDescription: This course explores the historical, social, and philosophical implications of mathematics and science through investigations of significant episodes in their history. Students are brought to understand that science and mathematics are not merely body of facts, theories, and techniques but involve diverse processes by which they are continually generated and reformulated.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research on historical episodes of STEM
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Presentation of historical, social, and philosophical implications of STEM
Discussion on different perspectives on STEM
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical evaluation of scientific and mathematical theories
Investigation of significant episodes in STEM history
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of diverse processes in STEM
Coordination of continual generation and reformulation of STEM theories

courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in mathematics in grades PreK-6 in support of NCTM national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of NCTM national instructional standards
Understanding of Virginia Standards of Learning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Creating activities to aid in solving mathematical problems
Analyzing children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and mathematical concepts

courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in science in grades PreK-6 in support of AAAS national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of AAAS national instructional standards
Understanding of Virginia Standards of Learning
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of instructional strategies to various learning styles
Assessment and improvement of educational activities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and execution of science-focused educational activities
Development and implementation of lesson plans adhering to instructional standards

courseDescription: Internship in school. Available for pass/fail grading only. Offers prospective teacher candidates a culminating experience that provides them with the tools needed for their first teaching jobs. Students are immersed in a local secondary school for 10 consecutive weeks and experience the expectations, processes, and rewards of teaching. As part of their Apprentice Teaching experience, candidates will be required to attend a one hour weekly seminar that will bring them together with master teachers to share experiences and to explore issues, problems, concerns, and processes related to their teaching experiences and to entering the profession of teaching.

Following a theory into practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in mathematics in grades PreK-6 in support of NCTM national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of NCTM national instructional standards
Understanding of Virginia Standards of Learning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promoting children's development of attitudes and behaviors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of theory into practice philosophy

courseDescription: Following a theory into practice philosophy, students explore, develop, and use instructional strategies, materials, technologies, and activities to promote children's development of attitudes, behaviors, and concepts in science in grades PreK-6 in support of AAAS national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Creation and use of educational materials
Implementation of activities to promote science education
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Promotion of developmental attitudes and behaviors
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting instructional strategies to fit diverse learning needs
Aligning teaching methods with AAAS national instructional standards and the Virginia Standards of Learning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organization of instructional activities
Leading science education initiatives in a PreK-6 environment

courseDescription: The advanced study of selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest which, due to their specialized nature, may not be offered regularly. These courses will appear in the course schedule.

This course will focus on the following elements of effective teaching practice:  understanding discipline specific content and methods, employing best-practice strategies to teach discipline specific skills and concepts, assessing student learning, legal and safety issues, use of technology, issues of diversity, engagement with the community, and strategies for continuing to grow as a teacher and learner.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing issues of diversity
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Employing best-practice strategies to teach discipline-specific skills and concepts
Strategies for continuing to grow as a teacher and learner
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Understanding legal and safety issues in education
Strategies for continuing to grow as a leader

courseDescription: A multidisciplinary course designed to provide insights about the fundamental concepts and basis for STEM education programs.  Standards for the school subjects of science, technology, engineering education and mathematics literacy will be reviewed.  Connections between these subjects will be explored.

courseTitle: Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Connection and Integration
courseDescription: A course designed to teach how to plan integrated STEM curriculum and instructional materials.  A review of projects that have undertaken STEM integration will be made.  Students will learn how to map STEM content and then design STEM integrated curriculum and instructional materials.

Order and structure the discipline of technology by identifying and analyzing the component parts and examining technical means as critical variables in the affairs of humankind.  Based on the Standards for Technological Literacy.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Examining technical means as critical variables
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ordering and structuring the discipline of technology

courseDescription: Analyze the technical concepts common and unique to the technical systems of technology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of common and unique technical concepts

courseDescription: Plan and develop effective program in technology related activities. Focus is on identification and development of resources, activities, and materials for classroom programs.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adjusting program plans based on available resources

courseDescription: Topics.

A multidisciplinary course designed to provide insights about the fundamental concepts and basis for STEM education programs.  Standards for the school subjects of science, technology, engineering education and mathematics literacy will be reviewed.  Connections between these subjects will be explored.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of science, technology, engineering and mathematics standards
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading interdisciplinary discussions on STEM subjects

courseTitle: Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Connection and Integration
courseDescription: A course designed to teach how to plan integrated STEM curriculum and instructional materials.  A review of projects that have undertaken STEM integration will be made.  Students will learn how to map STEM content and then design STEM integrated curriculum and instructional materials.

Order and structure the discipline of technology by identifying and analyzing the component parts and examining technical means as critical variables in the affairs of humankind.  Based on the Standards for Technological Literacy.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with Standards for Technological Literacy
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the component parts of technology
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ordering and structuring the discipline of technology
Identifying critical variables in technological affairs

courseDescription: Analyze the technical concepts common and unique to the technical systems of technology.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of common and unique technical concepts
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Comparing and contrasting different technical systems

courseDescription: Plan and develop effective program in technology related activities. Focus is on identification and development of resources, activities, and materials for classroom programs.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of program plans and resources
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of suitable resources for technology education
Analysis and evaluation of classroom activities

courseDescription: Topics.
